bibl.title: Letter from Richard Messer to Henry Rose Carter, June 21, 1921

div1.p: Messer thanks Carter for his comments on Virginia malaria control work.

div1.head: Letter from Richard Messer to Henry Rose Carter, June 21, 1921
div1.opener:
ENNION G. WILLIAMS, M. D.
STATE HEALTH COMMISSIONER
ROY K. FLANNAGAN, M. D.
ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
RICHARD MESSER
CHIEF ENGINEER
M. E. BRYDON, M. D.
DIRECTOR CHILD WELFARE
Commonwealth of Virginia
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
RICHMOND
Malaria-- General
June 21, 1921.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:-
div1.p:
I was very much interested in reading your letter
of the 20th concerning our report on malaria.

Table III is somewhat misleading. The heading should
have read “Showing Type of Community in which Control Work has been done
in Former Years and the Division of Funds in 1920”. We thought of
changing this heading but when the report was rewritten we forgot to
make the correction. The sub-heading 1-10 under population means popu-
lation between one and ten thousand. I note that this was not very clear.

With regard to counties worked in Virginia, there
were none worked during 1920 but one was under way at the time the report
was written and since then work has been started in two more counties.

Concerning question3, Texas should have been listed
as a cooperative state.

Concerning the seventeen control units credited to
Virginia in Table III, it should have been stated that this means those
in which control work has been done during the last five or six years or
since the malaria work in Virginia was started.

Thanking you again for your comments on the report
and with best wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Richard Messer
Chief Engineer. Richard Messer
AG
